text: I like Vaush's content, but in this debate he is being an a$$hole. He exploits that his partner is a foreign speaker and can't talk and formulate his thoughts as quickly as him. The German guy is a journalist and his knowledge in statistics is not deep enough to explain the (otherwise correct-ish) idea behind his "there is no correlation" argument. By definition, there IS a correlation, but we do not know whether it is PREDICTIVE until we collect more data. This is what he wanted to say, but could not because Vaush did not let him explain. The truth IS that based on the CO2-temperature data presented in the debate alone, we do not know if current climate change is man-made or not. But this does not imply that it is not a problem. The argument about mitigation OR adaptation is bullshit. It is not an either/or question. We will need BOTH and we need to stop arguing about it.

text:
The problem is you are dead wrong. Most climate studies you can pull up show the same few trends:

1) Solar luminosity continues to rise consistently through it's lifetime. This has been going on since the birth of the Sun. This of course fluctuates slightly but the overall trend is parabolic increasing over the giga geologic time scale. We also know that relative sunspot activity seems to not affect global temperature in any significant way and that the luminosity of the sun doesn't appear to be a main driver to climate change but plays a supporting role. This is observed fact.

2) We know that the early earth glacial periods were due to low luminosity and the interchange of heavy methane atmosphere to eventually normal CO2 load that the Earth could handle/generate. Since we know that sunspots and solar irradiance is not main driver, it was determined that the major factor in heat retention must be the greenhouse gas effect. Again we know this because we are able to measure the temperature of the stratosphere vs the trophosphere. If solar irradiance was the main driver, we would expect the stratosphere to have relative temperature gradients to the trophosphere. This does not happen. This is observed fact.

3) We combine all lines of evidence together: solar luminosity, greenhouse gases natural and man made, as well as sunspot solar cycles and we very clearly see the major driver nudging the scale of global temperature rise is the amount of CO2 we have dumped into the atmosphere. From the industrial revolution, onwards it is major spike and it's clearly coming from human activities.

In conclusion, it's clear that humans are causing global temperature averages to rise from an observation level and from a common sense level. You can't just keep dumping CO2 into the atmosphere and just expect nothing to react. Combined with the inevitable natural rise of solar luminosity, again occurs in the giga range of the geologic time scale, and other possible heating factors from sunspot activity (negligible cooling to global temperature) and volcanic activity (typically cooling effect if enough dust is kicked up into the atmosphere) we can clearly see that the rise in CO2 due to human industrial activity is the data that is tipping the scale.

text:
‚ÄúThe cause of nearly every mass extinction was by loss of temperature.‚Äù

Not 100% true, but not 100% false. Likewise, not every mass extinction event was caused by an increase in temperature.

Ordovician, 445 MYA: Two main causes; 

1. The southward movement of the supercontinent Gondwana caused the sea levels to rise and fall over several million years, wiping out habitats gradually. 
2. It is suggested that a late-Ordovician ice age as well as general change in water chemistry was enough to kill off massive swaths of marine invertebrates.

Late-Devonian - 370 MYA: Two events, the Kellwasser Event and the Hagenberg Event. 

The Kellwasser Event involved a high amount of surface eutrophication, in which the water is covered so thickly in algae that it is unable to absorb sunlight, and not allowing anoxic bottom water to flow to the surface.

The Hagenberg Event was the rapid increase of terrestrial plants that absorbed greenhouse gasses, substantially reducing the temperature of the earth and causing the sea level fall from increased glaciation in the Southern Hemisphere.

Permian Extinction, PT, ‚ÄúThe Great Dying‚Äù - 252 MYA: A gradual increase in global climate temperature followed by a MASSIVE amount of global seismic activity, partially aided by asteroidal impact, caused a flurry of volcanic eruptions and sea floor spreading, releasing toxic greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. This event suffocated and burned 95% of marine life and 70% of terrestrial life alive. 

Triassic-Jurassic Extinction - 201 MYA: The cause of this event is a mystery. Scientists have proposed climate change or asteroidal impact, but no hard evidence has been found as to what caused this event.

Cretaceous Extinction Event - 65 MYA: The most recent mass-extinction event and the best understood. This is the one that you were taught about likely before you could form complete sentences. A gradual increase in seismic activity and climate change, and an asteroid impact that greatly increased the speed of both. The asteroid hit the Gulf of Mexico, killing most life on earth all on its own in a matter of 10 hours. This caused a massive shift in the earth‚Äôs tectonic structure, causing a global series of earthquakes, tsunamis, and volcanic eruptions. The eruptions caused a rain of burning ash to carpet the earth, trapping all life in a burning furnace. This EVENTUALLY results in the overall cooling of the planet, which combined with a lack of sunlight did kill off a sizable amount of Earth‚Äôs population. But it was not the primary cause.

Holocene Extinction - Present Day: Scientists consider humans the cause of the next extinction event, through global domination, mass killing for sustaining the growing population, and the destruction of habitats to make room for their own. All of this is causing a series of global climate phenomena that could very well wipe us from existence.

text:
As a stats major, the climate change denier is a moron. Not only is it standard to use sample sizes of 30, not 30 samples like he claims, but the number that is needed isn't that simple. It depends both on the field of study and on what distribution your data follows. Additionally, this standard can be lowered further if you know your distribution and so you use that distribution to model instead of a normal approximation. That being said, not only do we meet the requirements for normal approximation with climate change, but we also know the distribution of the parameters, so we can actually exceed the level of accuracy needed even further by using a better model. Basically, we have an overwhelming amount data, more than enough to meet this guy's admittedly arbitrary requirements. Additionally, the denier is either ignorant of basic statistics (what he's incorrectly referencing is the Central Limit Theorem, which is taught an entry level stats class, which at my university every student is required to take for generals), or he is deliberately lying. Given how he cites Newton's laws of physics later on, which is stupid for a variety of reasons, I'm pretty sure it's both.

Also Vaush, rising temperature does lead to rising CO2, since the solubility of CO2 as carbonate ions decreases the higher the temperature is, so carbonate in the ocean evaporates as CO2 into the atmosphere (as a side note, the concentration of carbonate has increased enough to start killing a variety of species and destabilize a ton of underwater ecosystems in spite of the climate being hotter. If the warming were natural, the carbonate concentration would decrease). The causation goes the other way too, they both feed into eachother.

text: This was actually a satisfactory debate and Vaush did win despite the name calling and insults which was immature and unnecessary.  I agree that the evidence on climate change is real and open to being falsifiable but I disagree with the means of combating it with a carbon tax and global governance which does nothing to mitigate climate change.  If any, the investment should go into alternative energy and incentivizing energy renewable technology with rebates and open public investment in a free market.  There are many alternatives such as tidal, wind, solar, and nuclear.  Nuclear waste is still a problem to manage but it‚Äôs something we need to figure out other than burying it into the ground.  How we obtain energy is an interesting frontier to explore in the future.  It is a deep interest of mine as someone who studied Environmental Science.

text: The trick is to manipulate the scales of the lines of overlapping graphs with different units. You can overinflate the scale of one, say temperature, and small, random shifts (noise) look like major changes (signal). You can then greatly minimize the scale of the other (CO2 ppm) line so that it looks like there is no significant change whatsoever.

text:
OH YES. The Oregon-Petition. Signed by all the important scientists like... the Spice Girls, Mickey Mouse and f*cking Charles Darwin. Some names are listed multiple times and only 0,5% of the signatories have any expertise in climate science. Some of them had no idea that their names were on the list.
And YES. CO2 emissions by humans are just a small part of the total emissions per year, BUT the natural emissions are part of a cycle and in the end the total amount of CO2 in the atmosphere remains roughly in balance. Ya know. It's like our planet breathes in and out. 
AND YES. Water vapor is also a greenhouse parts. And it's part of every calculation. Because CO2-caused temperature risings causes more water vapor in the atmosphere and that causes a positive feedback loop which doubles the effect. Every 1¬∞C change caused by CO2 causes an additional 1¬∞C increase by water vapor. So yeah, thanks for mentioning. Because it makes climate change a lot worse.
AND YES. Methane is a more potent greenhouse gas than CO2, like 20 times stronger, but there is more than 200 times more CO2 in the atmosphere. But yeah, reducing methane emissions is important, too.

text: I think both descriptions of the greenhouse effect could have been better - don't think of it as a green house, there is no roof, it's the infrared portion of sunlight that gets absorbed by the CO2 as it passes through it towards the ground - it doesn't reflect much off the earth unless it's bright (the albido effect) like off ice n snow, so some gets absorbed into the ground/ things on the ground. There's also a heating effect from the scattering of visible light but it's marginal. You can then see how this effect can be studied in the lab, using a tank of different synthetic atmospheres and heating them with IR lamps. Yay science.

1) Extremely overscales the temperature axis - it shows practically consistent temperatures within less than 0.8¬∞C difference (compared to earth's average temperature of around 290K), yet makes it look like it fluctuates dramatically, whereas CO2 rises by over 100%.
2) Only shows the northern hemisphere. It's well known that temperature fluctuates stronger the more locally you apply it. Many temperature trends observable on one hemisphere practically disappear once you look at the whole globe (like the European Medieval Warmth Period and "little Ice Age"). These stronger short-term fluctuations also contribute to masking long-term  changes like global warming.
3) Ignores impacts of known climate patterns like the El Nino/La Nina cycles, which create natural fluctuations that can sometimes mask longer term effects like those of CO2. 
4) Starts and ends at arbitrary dates and can thus hide greater trends, most importantly of course the tremendous warming since the 20th century.

And most importantly: Over earth's history you indeed do not see a direct correlation between temperature and CO2. But neither do you see one between the intensity of the sun and temperatures, even though it should be absolutely obvious that higher sun intensity warms the planet.
The solution to both of these problems is that once you combne both sun intensity and CO2 concentration, you get a perfect correlation with temperature. CO2 is thus the overwhelming earthly driver of earth's climate. Especially right now when there is little change from the sun (the predicted impact of varying levels of sun power for the foreseeable future is less than 1¬∞C, usually even less than 0.5¬∞C).

text:
As a geologist/palaeontologist, this guys misuse of past climate data really grinds my gears.
His Phanerozoic temp curve is out of date and there are many more factors than CO2 determining temp in the past. We're also not recovering from an ice age, we should be descending into a new one - climate change would be much worse if we weren't.
Plus he has no concept of ecology. Just because its warmer doesn't mean everything is going to do better because plant productivity increases with temp and CO2 in controlled conditions.
And the point about there being more plants in the past, yes, it was when there were hardly any land animals and it sent the planet into an ice age.
One other thing that these bozos never grasp is that it isn't necessarily magnitude of change but the rate of change.

text:
"science isn't based on consensus" is a stupid thing to say. As someone like philosopher/historian of science Thomas Kuhn pointed out science goes through two periods : the first being "normal science" and the second being a "paradigm shift" wherein the consensus is overturned due to some new evidence (for instance Einstein's theory of relativity displacing previous "classical mechanics").

The difference between Einstein's theory and those of climate change deniers, is that Einstein published peer-reviewed articles with methodologies/theories that were used to verify later experiments by others. Climate Change deniers cannot produce a parsimonious alternative theory, so we can safely disregard them as cranks. At least until some serious experimentation coupled with repeated peer-reviewed studies can overturn the "normal science" we see ourselves in w/r/t climate science.

text: The reason there is no correlation in the past between CO2 and temperature is because there are other factors that influence the climate on our planet, most notably the sun and small changes in earth's orbit. These are what caused the latest ice age and the little ice age. Now that there are more greenhouse gases in the atmosphere it has become the primary influencer of the climate in our times. Note that the current rise in temperature at the same time as greenhouse gases are becoming more numerous COULD be a coincidence, but if that is true there must currently be something else that is having a stronger impact on the rising temperatures than CO2 and methane. What would that be? You tell me, i have no idea.

text:
did you know that in summer 2019 the German alt-right party AfD issued a minor interpellation in the Bundestag to check whether the number about the 97 % of scientists was correct. And the response to that was, that actually 99.94 % of scientists agree that climate change is man-made


edit: and the 0.3 %, coincidentally, are the percentage of scientists who made an explicit statement about the cause of global warming but still ended up being neutral about whether it was man-made or not, in the sense that they were uncertain. Out of all the papers, examined in the study, 32.6% say that climate change is man-made. But since 66.7% of all papers don't state any evaluation of the cause of global warming at all, out of only those that do state an opinion, ~97% say it's man-made. That's how you get the 97%. You can look up the study easily, it's called "Quantifying the consensus onanthropogenic global warming in the
scientific literature". He literally just repeated somebody else's misreading of the study.

text: I took a picture of that graph on the screen share and did some measurements of pixels, looks like the graph ends around 1953 +- 4 years. That's around the beginning of when scientists started noticing a rapid upward curve in global average temperature if I recall correctly. There were scientists earlier than that who talked about potential ecological disaster from the atmospheric pollution of an industrialised world, but I believe it took until right around that range for people to start noticing a serious shift (likely due to the industrialisations of underdeveloped WWII nations, especially Russia and China). If someone has specific examples and years, shoot, but it's amusing how the graph cut things off right as scientists started seeing global warming.

text: It's actually really simple to prove that CO2 traps heat. If you take a photo using high frequency infared film, CO2 show up as transparent. If you took a picture with a lower frequency infared film, the CO2 would appear to be a white fog, meaning that it reflects said frequency. When high frequency infared light hits the surface of the earth, it is absorbed by objects and re-radiated in a broad range of frequencies. Some of these can pass through the atmosphere, while others are trapped by CO2. this is actually the principal that radiative coolers work off of: contain heat until it can reach a frequency that isn't absorbed by the atmosphere, allowing it to dissipate into space.

text:
another thing, the whole "more CO2 = more plants" thing is basic biology.

Plants have stomas, which is how they "breath" in the air. When they open their stoma, they lose moisture.
So, in theory, yeah, more CO2 means more plants BUT you need to make sure they're getting more water at the same time otherwise they just dry up and die.
If CO2 is warming the planet, that means there's likely to be less water where plants are.

text: It's been about a few decades now since I became aware of the climate change denialists. In all that time I've still never understood why climate change action is considered 'left-wing'. It just makes no sense to me, okay so you have to make some drastic changes but Conservatives never seem to take issue with all the drastic changes caused by tax cuts or austerity policies that affect peoples lives directly, they are all for that. So why is it suddenly bad to make changes to improve the environment? You can scream all you want about why it's a myth, that still doesn't explain why you think doing something about the climate is 'leftist'. It's at that point that I realised how tribalistic the whole debate is, Conservatives don't push against climate change policy for any ideological reason, they do it because their opponents are pushing for climate change. That's all there is to it.

text:
Vaush, the bigger problem with his graph is he's only comparing to CO2 levels. He's doing what climate change "skeptics" accuse the scientists of, ignoring the sun. CO2 isn't the only factor on the timescales he's looking at. When you add in solar forcing the CO2 correlation becomes clear.

Edit: also he's correct about the temperature lag and CO2 increase after temperatures increase. There are feedback mechanisms where increased temperatures lead to increased CO2 which leads to increased temperatures, etc. All of these things are expected based on current models. They are mostly irrelevant talking points.

text: If anyone is wondering, the initial graph over the past billion or so years that this man pretends proves no correlation between CO2 and temperature actually proves the opposite. That graph is commonly held up by anti science quacks, and while the data is real, the application of it is, very unsurprisingly, extremely biased. The reason is because it ONLY considers CO2, and it ignores the output of the sun. The sun has steadily been increasing in output for the past billion or so years, and it was only at around 70% of its current output 500 million years ago. Once both factors are combined, the correlation is very strong. Watch this video from the excellent youtuber Potholer54 to see what I am talking about. https://youtu.be/OJ6Z04VJDco?t=340

text:
One fun thing I found when researching this is that the guy TECHNICALLY isn¬¥t wrong when he says the greenhouse effect doesn¬¥t exist. That is exactly the thing that those three profs he kept mentioning proved. Essentially, this boils down to "greenhouse effect" is a popular term meant to explain the effects of climate change through analogy. It is a rather poor analogy since it has 0 basis in actual physics. So the model Vaush draws is wrong. HOWEVER the fact that "greenhouse effect" is a shitty analogy doesn¬¥t mean that "greenhouse gases" don¬¥t exist and don¬¥t have a profound effect on the climate, something which probably even the guys who wrote the papers "disproving" the greenhouse effect would admit. amazingly this idiot managed to cherry-pick the exact parts that helping without acknowledging any context
TL;DR The guy is technically correct about physics, but is still a hack
If anyone is interested in the science, here ya go:
https://scienceofdoom.com/2012/01/05/kramm-dlugi-on-dodging-the-greenhouse-bullet/
https://scienceofdoom.com/2010/04/05/on-the-miseducation-of-the-uninformed-by-gerlich-and-scheuschner-2009/
https://scienceofdoom.com/2010/03/14/on-having-a-laugh-by-gerlich-and-tscheuschner-2009/

text:
Just watched a great video on this recent, and just as a point of clarification, the debater is actually correct that in the past there has been a significant time lag between Temperature Changes and CO2 changes.  Temperature has always come first followed by a CO2 change approx. 800-1000 years later.  This is due to the way gas dissolves into liquids, higher temperature == less gas dissolved in oceans => more gas in the atmosphere.  Lower temperature == more gas dissolved in oceans => less gas in atmosphere.  https://youtu.be/uqwvf6R1_QY?t=763

This is all to say that increasing the amount of gas in the atmosphere would have a significant and tangible effect on the heating of the planet because releasing more CO2 means that the same amount of gas is able to dissolve into the oceans but more CO2 is available to heat the planet => more CO2 is released from the oceans due to lower solubility => more heating (so on and so forth).  If anything, his point about Temperature changes leading CO2 changes is a cause for even more panic.  That is to say that literally, we could be facing a catastrophic amount of CO2 release in the next 800-1000 years as less gas is able to be dissolved into the oceans and is slowly released, even if we completely stopped CO2 emissions today.

text:
There are a lot of people with PhDs in unrelated fields making claims about climate science.  You can be an actual rocket scientist and not understand the information presented in an unrelated field.

This differs from the true idiots (or possibly con artists) who will assert untrue things.  A good example being the people who claim that temperature increase is due to solar forcing, while ignoring the fact that the period has been a descent into a solar minimum.

The link between CO2 content and heat retention in the atmosphere was figured out in the nineteenth century, with actual documentaries warning of the likely effects from increasing CO2 concentration being produced in the early 1960s (following the scientific consensus of the 1950s that, yes, putting billions of tonnes of additional CO2 into the atmosphere would indeed trap more heat).  This German bozo and his kind are arguing against long-proven science.  They‚Äôre barely above ‚ÄòFlat-Earthers‚Äô for credibility.

text:
About 25+ years ago, I was reading articles posted by Nasa, revealing several other planets in our Solar System were also exhibiting symptoms of Global warming and the articke went on to say they believed it was due to increasing Cosmic radiation passing through from outer space.
Then it became political and they seemed to forget their own words..
But i didn't...
So, how might increasing radiation affect our climate?
History clearly the Sun has regular cycles of change that affect our climate.
As with everything else, the medua ignores it, as do those pushing CO2 as the primary cause of Climate change.
Given CO2 is 1/2200 of our atmosphere, the argument is weak to begin with.
Water vapor is by far the largest component of Green house gases, but you cant blame anyone towards political and financial gain by referencing this fact.
If you wish to follow this long winded note i will explain how it works.
-Every 230-260 years the sun's dynamic output, being heat and light varies 
Valentina Zharkova, a mathematician and Astrophysicist, combined all ezisting studies and reviewed Nasa data.
Zharkova developed a predictive algorithm that has been extremely accurate over the last ten years in predicting present changes.
Seven years ago she predicted sunspota would largely disappear, reflective of the changes occuring beneath the suns surface.
Over the last few years sunspots have literally disappeared.
Data shows three distinct fields of circulating plasma, always interracting, sometimes inhibiting and sometimes reinforcing total wavelength output.
Think three phase in electricity.
Consider a small motor, as it ramps up and down its output varies as does it electromagnetic field.
The motor is stable, as is the sun.
As sunlight passes three a changing electromagnetic field, so does the light passing through it, presently the suns light is dimming.
The magnetosphere, an invisible shield generated by the suns magnetic field is correspondingly weakening.
The magnetosphere surrounding the earth and sun protects us from excessive Cosmic and Solar radiation.
More is passing through the magnetosphere, warming our atmosphere, land and water.
As the oceans warm they release greenhouse gas, which include CO2.
Glacial ice samples show heating of the atmosphere has always occured prior to CO2 increase, and vice versa.
The oceans provide a huge sync for absorption of gases, but when the oceans warm, these gases are forced out of dissolved suspension.
CO2 then increases.
Cosmic radiation entering ionize particles in our atmosphere, which attract, grow in size, attract moisture and form clouds.
This seeding leads to more unpredictable rainfall and flooding.
Japanese researchers studied eruptions from four volcanoes over a 306 year period.
9 of the 11 eruptions, with near certainty occured during a period of low magnetic activity on the sun.
Researchers went on to theorize that muons within the silica rumich lava were being stimulated, causing more volcanic and earthquake activuty.
This is exactly what we saw in the 1800's when the climate was cold with heightened volcanic activity.
Consider the flow of nature, the sun has created the heat, it now works to reduce it, in natures balance of change.
Reduced irradiance or weakened sunlight , along with increased cloud cover will cool our plant.
It is not warm that we must now consider, it is steadily worsening cold, with summers shorter and offset growing seasons.
This will happen over several years, hot will still be experienced as the change occurs.
This topic has been hijacked.
People knew this cycle was going to happen, they just decided to create a story that would benefit them towards political and financial control

The whole Theory thing is wrong. All you need for a theory is that it can make accurate predictions.

This is why in cosmology when scientists are making theories based on the cosmic microwave background they use a tiny part of the dataset so they can go given a, b, c then x and see if that is true. If they built the theory based on the whole dataset it would fit the data but it would have no testable predictive power and be completely worthless.

text:
It is true that co2 lags temperature on geological timeframes because (big shock) co2 doesn't actually cause most of the warming, its mostly caused by an increase of water vapour in the air.  There are a number of amplifying systems that cause the earth to warm such as the albedo effect or forest dieback but all of them need an initial push, that push has always been greenhous gases but the rate at which they are increasing today is unparalleled in the geological timeframe.  We're more than a push we're a fucking roundhouse kick.  The real danger of climate change that people dont seem to talk about is reaching whats known as tipping points where the whole thing rolls completely out of our control. ======================================== VARIOUS SOURCES ===================================
 https://ipcc.ch/sr15                                                                                                                                                                   https://skepticalscience.com/co2-lags-temperature.htm                                                                                           https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=52KLGqDSAjo&list=PL82yk73N8eoX-Xobr_TfHsWPfAIyI7VAP

Gotta say. I was kinda disappointed with Vaush in this. This other guy came with a ton of basic myths on this issue, and Vaush seemed unprepared to answer a few of them.

Idk how much Vaush has debated this in the past, but his inability to argue against the claim that there is no correlation between CO2 and temp, and his inability to explain the 800-year lag was pretty frustrating.

First, yes. That guy is "technically" correct. There is no literal correlation between temp and CO2. That's bc CO2 isn't the ONLY factor in temperature. Other factors include the suns output and aerosols. CO2 is one of the main dials, but its not until you factor in the other things as well you see the real correlation. Its the same reason people on that side of this issue will never argue the sun's output and temperature are not correlated (and like CO2, they're not on their own). Its bc there's other factors outside of just the sun. But a lack of perfect correlation between CO2 and temp doesn't disprove CO2's role in temp increase.

Its like trying to figure out why you're broke. Was it the drugs? Fast food? Or parties? "Well when you look at the correlation between your money and the amount of parties you throw, there is no correlation." Fair, but is it fair to say that means it's completely unrelated? No. Especially when we all know I'm throwing hella parties. Of course on its own the correlation won't mean anything, but combined with the other key factors that we can actively check, there is an obvious correlation.

On the 800-year lag. I've linked a video to potholer54 down below. He addresses this myth on both sides. He also addresses the "only 4% of CO2 in the atmosphere comes from humans" claim.

https://youtu.be/FBF6F4Bi6Sg

One other thing I want to add is about the people paid by oil companies to find contradictory evidence. Those people are few and far between. That was what oil companies intended to do decades ago, but their scientists came to the same exact conclusion as the government and public scientists. So that is actually a myth for the most part as well.

That seems not to be much, but if we compare it to the difference from the lowest temperature in the little ice age, which was 1.5 degrees lower than today, it is not a big difference from that. But keep in mind during the little ice age the Thames was frozen over 26 times. So for the nature it sure makes a big difference. On the other hand, if you divide 0.9 by the 170 years passed it makes an increase of just 0.0053 degrees per year. 
In other terms you have to grow very old to see and feel a significant difference in that.
Now since there is this wavyness in it, some people tend to arbitrary chose a sequence out of these waves that shows a steep increse i.e. from 1970 to 2000. text: ¬†@Oldinea Miller¬† I think you're strawmanning what scientists mean when they say unprecedented.  But to be honest I think you're sincere and not doing it on purpose.  So when they say unprecedented they don't mean the drastic change in climate itself.  It's a fact that dinosaurs lived in an atmosphere with even more co2 than what we have.  What's unprecedented is the rate.  Things haven't changed this fast. We know this because for example let's look at ocean acidification.  That happens alongside co2 in the atmosphere. It sets off reactions that, without enough buffers, results in acidification.  And we haven't really seen this before because normally rock and stone would create chemical buffers to additional co2 but that's only if co2 rises slowly. Think of it like an assembly line. Runs smoothly unless you clog it with more than it can process. And that clog. And the rate of the clog. That's what scientists are saying is unprecedented.  Honestly youd have to think scientists are mighty stupid to not be aware of earth's changing climate over thousand of years/ eons

text:
¬†@Oldinea Miller¬† See, slight problem with that video. Its an op-ed piece with no firm and reliable sources that can be verified externally. That is not a source that can be cited in any way. It is the equivalent of using a geocities website that hosts a blog from a guy who collects gossip as a primary source for a research paper on a historic figure. The rule of thumb is three confirming first hand sources, and it is valid. For second or third hand information like your video contains, unless it is used to corroborate externally viable accounts of other events (i.e. a personal journal that mentions something that they heard in conjunction with official reports on a subject), it is insufficient to draw any real conclusions from. Also, nice derail, try and stick to the topics at hand.

TLDR: your video is bunk, find a better source of facts, and give me back the 15 minutes I wasted watching it and the 45 minutes I spent trying to verify it with real sources.

text:
¬†@COTD¬† [Sorry in advance for the essay]

Cite a source for your claims. "I heard it on the news" means nothing. I found one case of a Colorado coroner complaining about the fact that all people who died with COVID but not because of it, were classified as "deaths among cases". An attentive reader should realise immediatly that this isn't the same thing as being reported as a co-morbidity. Colorado and the CDC differentiate between "deaths due to COVID19" and "deaths among COVID19 cases".

It's pretty well explained here:
"The state health department says the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention requires them to report people who‚Äôve died with COVID-19 in their systems because it‚Äôs crucial for public health surveillance.

Colorado provides death data related to COVID-19 in two ways:

Deaths due to COVID-19:
This is based on CDC coding of death certificates where COVID-19 is listed as the cause of death or a significant condition contributing to death.
*Deaths among COVID-19 cases:
This reflects people who died with COVID-19, but COVID-19 may not have been the cause of death listed on the death certificate.*
CDPHE explains that they are required to report deaths among COVID-19 cases to the CDC.

‚ÄúThis information is required by the CDC and is crucial for public health surveillance, as it provides more information about disease transmission and can help identify risk factors among all deaths across populations,‚Äù stated CDPHE on its Frequently Asked Questions page.""
Source: https://denver.cbslocal.com/2020/12/15/grand-county-covid-deaths/

A few examples of what you could gather from documenting EVERYONE who died with COVID (just from my brain, I'm sure a scientist could explain it properly):
- Is COVID a risk factor during trauma surgery?
- Are late stage cancer patients more likely to catch COVID than people from the average population?
- What is the transmission rate inside of a hospital?
- What Hospitals/what parts of the country seem to have the best and worst handling of COVID in its hospitals (high transmission rate=bad)? How effective is change x or y?
- Are there illnesses that do not lead to higher rate of morbidity if the persom contracts COVID?
- How does COVID interact with hospital germs in infected patients?

Lets also not forget this data can be used to trace infection chains, which is probably most important thing to consider here.

Like I said, this is just a random row of examples, some of which might apply, I'm sure I probably missed a lot. There's no reason all people who died with COVID shouldn't be seperately reported (which they are, view quote) in Colorado and internationally. The CDC is doing everything right here.

author: S L

text:
As a physics major, whenever Oliver says anything about physics I die inside. In order to explain why the intuitive but physically vague analogies like Vaush's "cotton igloo" and such are correct, I'd need to go into quantum physics. There's no way I could explain it in under two hours for someone with both a high school education and any interest whatsoever in physics, let alone someone who claims that gas doesn't store heat or absorb light. Sure, I could give simpler physical explanations, but people like him would say "uh, no, air doesn't bend light" just like the classic "it's cold outside" meme, so I'd have to go deeper until they'd have no hope of disputing the physics without first educating themselves. It's pretty much the thing where a kid says "why" repeatedly, you gotta be prepared to explain your explanation of your explanation of your explanation of why the atmosphere captures heat.

To someone willing to accept scientific explanations, you could just quickly cover the basics. To someone educated in science, you could just quickly cover the math and physics at the core of the situation. To someone uneducated in science and unwilling to accept anything that isn't rooted in facts they can't possibly debunk, you have to painstakingly work up from the basics to the advanced stuff.

author: Schokobienen TV

text: Under that mindset, rational people are doomed to lose forever. I mean, it takes very little effort and time to deny basic science. Even if you can prove them wrong in under 30 minutes, by the time you're finished they jump to another ridiculous claim. These people aren't looking for the truth, they're mostly slightly intelligent, albeit irrational people with a MASSIVE ego and an axe to grind, so the objective shouldn't be convincing them. Instead, the goal should be to convince the audience, some of which is probably on the fence.
author: Pomponivs Archibald

text:
¬†@Pomponivs Archibald¬† For sure, the point is really just what you said, that science deniers need only deny the science, whereas anyone who wants to make a full, rational argument needs to spend a long time if they want to have a hope of convincing a science denier. Vaush does this with sociology, and from time to time popular YouTubers post extremely long-form content breaking down and debunking unscientific claims and then explaining the science from the ground up. Shaun posted a multiple-hour video a while back where he just completely took apart the position of race affecting IQ, and even the notion of IQ itself (which was quite interesting to listen to alongside busywork). That was a good example of what we need. The only problem is that just the length of the finished video alone was probably the amount of time the author of the book he was debunking put into the research at all. The sources were garbage and all were quite outdated and questionable, but the author only had to find the conclusions, quickly compile them, and then write out a bunch of fluff to pad it. YouTube videos don't even need to write the fluff unless the presenter is famous or posing as an academic, and even then, a script is comparatively easy to write when you have nothing to say. Compare that to Shaun, who had to meticulously show how bad each source was, debunking all the sources.

If we don't put all that effort into arguing the science, only assert the truth, then in the eyes of the science denier's audience, at best our assertion is as reliable as the denier's. Science isn't doomed to lose forever, but it is stuck being the side that needs to argue everything, rather than the side that can say something on authority and have it be accepted. That's mainly because of the "on authority" part. Scientific research should be and is questioned and re-evaluated as part of the scientific process, but that's a job for the experts, so that process never makes it to the general public. What reaches the general public is quite satisfactory by the steep scientific standards of today, but appears from the outside to be some monolithic "Science" entity declaring what is the truth, since nobody sees the internal, highly technical debate that led to the scientific community accepting something.

Basically, science has PR problems due to lack of transparency. Governments can just be more transparent, but science is opaque to anyone who doesn't understand the discussion. Three thousand years ago, anyone could understand Archimedes' "hey if I put ropes around pulleys like this, I can pull harder, give it a try." Good luck explaining the absorption and re-emission of photons by atomic electron clouds to someone who isn't familiar with chemistry or physics and inherently distrusts any scientific assumptions you make without having those assumptions explained in equal depth.

And now I've noticed how long this is. I wish I was this comfortable typing important emails.

*TL;DR:* If you don't fully explain the science, the denier's audience will see you've put as much evidence in as the denier, but they already distrust mainstream science, so you can't get far with them without putting a load of effort in. It's possible, but frustratingly slow.
author: CatOfTheNorth

text: ¬†@CatOfTheNorth¬† Thanks for the response. I understand what you're saying but I beg to disagree. There are indeed ways to present one's point without explaining all the science from the ground up. Most of the time it can be proven from the surface level. What purpose does it serve to explain quantum mechanics to a guy who probably equates it to magic? He'll deny the existence of probability clouds right away. In this case a chemist might have a more down to earth approach since they could draw comparisons from the mechanical properties of gases. Hell, even the term greenhouse effect itself is an example. When I first heard of it I was like 11. Not knowing what a greenhouse was, the concept confused me, but the moment I saw one everything was clear as day.
author: Pomponivs Archibald

text:
‚Äã¬†@Pomponivs Archibald¬† The difficulty is in the degree of how much someone misunderstands or mistrusts science. If you explain it to a child, they're very likely to accept it, since they have no reason to distrust it beyond just not having heard of the phenomenon before. Now that they have, they're willing to accept that it is the case. The more someone distrusts science, that is, the more fundamental the misunderstanding, the further back you have to go to correct the misunderstanding. If they disagree light works like particles or waves in the first place, good luck getting them to accept that photons can be absorbed, and in that process heat things up. If they have multiple unscientific reasons to believe the greenhouse effect is untrue, then you have to fight through every mechanism of the greenhouse effect, based on things they do accept, or mechanisms you've previously proven to them that way.

For example, if the only problem is that they think light is your eyes magically probing surfaces, you only have to go as far as proving light is a physical thing you can track through space and which interacts with matter, then you've cleared any misunderstanding and they'll likely accept the conclusion that light is absorbed by air. Science deniers do a lot more than this though, and that's why they're so effective. First they question mainstream science with something like "they're funded by shadowy cabals" or "they won't accept this [garbage] evidence" or whatever. That leaves the audience open to accepting a different assertion with less difficulty. Then they say something wrong like "light is not absorbed by air" and back it up with bad science and intuitive (but unscientific) explanations to cement the idea in the audience's minds. Now not only do you need to show that the sources are garbage, you need to convince them this whole process they believe in is false without making them feel stupid, because you don't want to be mean, but more importantly because they'll reject your argument otherwise.

A scientist or a slightly misguided layman need only have the claim challenged. The paper it's based on being bad science is enough to open them up to a more scientific explanation. It's not rooted in their worldview, unlike someone who has been deceived over a longer period of time on a whole topic. I have an anecdote demonstrating this between me and my dad. He believed that, at the same wattage, some space heaters were more effective than others. This is not true because all electrically-powered heaters are 100% efficient. 1500 watts of electricity in, 1500 watts of heat out. He believed this for two reasons. One was because they varied in price and were designed differently. Why would it be more expensive or designed differently if not to make it better at heating? The other was that he felt some heaters warmed him more than others. Standing in front of different heaters felt different, some feeling much hotter. For reference, a watt is a unit of power, and power is energy over time. A watt-hour is energy over time multiplied by time, so it's an amount of energy. That's why energy bills demand payment per watt-hour. Heating up a room by a degree takes an amount of energy, the time it takes depends on the power. More watts, faster heat.

First, I guaranteed him, on my knowledge as a physicist, that all equal power heaters emit the same heat. I cited the laws of thermodynamics in simple words, arguably the most fundamental laws of physics, and explained that the definition of energy efficiency inherently guarantees a heat generator will always be 100% efficient. That last bit was the hardest part, I had to explain that any process that produces energy of any form turns some of the input into heat, and that in the end, no matter what forms of energy a device puts out, it'll all be heat eventually. A fan pushes air around, and the moving air molecules rub against others, the air slows down, and heats up. Regardless of what happens to it, at bare minimum, if a heater sucks some amount of watts out of the power grid, the watts have to go somewhere.
Then, having established that a heater using 1500 watts is going to output 1500 watts in some form of energy, I had to explain that the design differences may make things feel different initially, but in the end, it will all turn into heat. If the heater uses 100 watts of its power on a fan blowing the heat, the heater might not feel as hot when standing next to it (fast moving air is colder and lower pressure), but the kinetic energy of the air will eventually dissipate and turn into the exact same amount of energy of heat. Standing in front of the heater, you feel the fan instead of the heat, but a thermometer across the room will only notice that at first, 1400 watts of heat are being added, and then soon after, 100 watts of heat start being added as well as the blown air from a moment ago slows down and heats up. 1500 watts total. Smaller heaters feel hotter in front of them because all the heat is coming out at the same spot. Heaters with fans distribute the heat for a more immediate effect on the overall room but a less immediate effect on the area right around them. However, in the long term, all heat the room the same amount.

Then he pretty much accepted it, because I went back as far as his misunderstanding of the science, and he now understands why each feels different. I didn't need to go any further, that was the extent of his misunderstanding. Heaters felt different, so he rationalised why. All I needed to do was give a proper explanation of why and give a very surface level explanation of the assumptions that lead my to explanation being true. After all, he had no reason to question basic thermodynamics, and the result is still an effect he can feel for himself. If he had been convinced that electricity or even energy itself doesn't work the way I say it does, I'd need to go all the way back to proving how those physical concepts work, then break apart his rationalisation based on that misunderstanding, then assert the truth. The longer someone spends deceived by science deniers, the more fortified and widespread their misunderstanding becomes. That's why people who go down the rabbit hole of conspiracy theories are so difficult to pull out of the rabbit hole, because they've built an entire worldview based on it, and now you need to meticulously break down every step they went through. You also need to prove your side more than science deniers did theirs, since it's more difficult to prove to a human brain that it's wrong than it is to prove that the brain is right or to give it something new but compatible with its beliefs. That's a concept in psychology termed "confirmation bias."

Dang, I did it again. I really like talking about science.

text: I don‚Äôt have time to watch the whole thing so idk if they mentioned this. But there are other processes that can contribute to lower global temperatures and higher CO2 levels. The meridian also overturning cycle which supplies Earth with most of its heat can possibly stop due to rising global temperatures and glacial melt. Check out Lake Agassiz and how it contributed to a quick cold snap in the young dryas period.

text:
That guy was actually correct on one point. Sometimes CO2 has lagged behind warming. This is, of course, well known within the scientific community. Sometimes, due to factors such as the earth moving closer to the sun, the earth experiences an increase in its temperature. This increase initiates a feedback loop by which CO2 is released from the oceans, furthering the warming and continuing the cycle.
That guy is still a complete lunatic, but have to acknowledge when Vaush is wrong. 

You can find the article here: https://pubs.giss.nasa.gov/abs/lo03000u.html
With a good summary here: https://skepticalscience.com/co2-lags-temperature.htm

I remember a Climate Change Denier saying Humans contribute maybe 1% to at most 3% and thus it is ridiculous that Humans could be the cause or having any affect on the rising temperatures etc.

Say you have a bathtub that has a faucet with a 1 gal per minute flow and a drain of 1 gal per min. There would be no standing water in the bathtub other than the seconds around the drain itself. Now imagine increasing the faucet by 1%. In 100 minutes there is going to be a gallon of standing water in the bathtub. In 6 hours 6 gallons of standing water.  In 12 hours 12 gallons of standing water. Eventually the bathtub will overflow.

Btw if all the humans died then all the plants that we have cut down would grow back and more CO2 would be absorbed. All the cities would be overrun with foliage within a short period of time.

text: Tropical species ranges are also expanding, and temperate species are moving more and more northward. Sessile species like most plants which can only disperse via reproduction have a much more difficult time modifying their ranges in the time scale necessary to remain in their physiological range of tolerance. Also, ocean acidification is a massive problem; the ocean is the largest carbon sink, and overloading the atmosphere with carbon containing compounds since the industrial revolution is driving up the production of carbonic acid in the ocean, thus causing a decrease in ocean pH. The oceans are usually very slightly basic, but are on the way to becoming slightly acidic, and while that may seem small, the pH scale is logarithmic, and many marine organisms which rely on the ability to build calcium carbonate structures will no longer be able to do so if the pH drops even slightly. These organisms make up a large portion of secondary consumers and subsequently a large section of the ocean trophic web, and their extinction would have dramatic cascading effects up the food web. During the Eocene, when atmospheric carbon levels were also uncharacteristically high, there was very very little marine biodiversity because of the relatively low pH. Additionally, environmental health is measured by biodiversity, and not every species benefits from a single standard environmental variable because every species is adapted to a different niche and a different range of tolerance, and the loss of one species or clade can impact the resilience of whole ecosystems. The idea that "species only go extinct when it gets cold and a warmer earth would just be better for all species" is not only dramatically stupid but reflects a dangerous amount of ecological ignorance that unfortunately the average person probably isn't equipped enough to sus out.

text:
This guy heard about the Milankovitch Cycle once and just went on a mad one holy shit.

For anyone wondering - the Earth does have a cycle of warming and cooling (each cycle lasts around 100,000 years and is caused by the tilt of the Earth changing due to the gravity of the other bodies in the solar system pulling on us), and in those cycles CO2 rises AFTER the temperature does, because the extra heat warms the oceans and warm liquids hold CO2 worse than cold ones. However based on our current point in the cycle we should be going back down in temperature, and CO2 should be reducing. Except neither of those is happening. The current rise in climate temp is down to greenhouse gases/industrialisation, we just happened to choose the worst time for it because we were already at pretty much peak temps.

author: Asmylia

text:
There are lots of reasons why rising temperature can cause rising CO2 and that's what makes climate change so terrifying: positive feedback loops. We're seeing two right now with the forest fires and the melting of the permafrost - temperature rises a bit, things go on fire/permafrost melts, which releases CO2 (or methane), which increases the temperature, which causes more things to happen that release CO2 (or methane), which increases the temperature etc.

Deniers think they're being clever when they point out "first temperature, then CO2" but their tiny brains refuse to accept that it can only take a tiny increase in temperature from something like increased solar activity to trigger a disastrous runaway greenhouse effect from initially small quantities of released CO2. In this case, fossil fuels are that trigger.

These feedback loops are everywhere, just waiting to be set in motion. Six degrees of warming means the end of our species.

We can directly measure gases and their reflective rate per molecular structure... as well as measure the make-up of our atmosphere. There is a mathematically causative relational effect to be expected if said make-up changes. CO2 alone is hardly the direct or lone cause, gases like methane are making things worse, as well. And of course there hasn't been anything previous in history, mankind as we know it has industrialized once. What a dumb take. But the German dude did get Vaush into the CO2 trap, nonetheless. It isn't a "do this one thing about that" as an issue.

If anything, didn't recent studies show that the lack of movement due to covid-19 did little to dent climate change further implying that corporations are the biggest problem in our climate issues? This covers a broad range, of course, but they're large corporations nonetheless. Livestock to energy.

I'd get away from the CO2 centered argument. This is multi-pronged argument and it is just hanging Vaush up on the one.

text:
do climate change deniers know that without a greenhouse effect physics have no way to explain how warm the earth is right now? like quite literally the earth would be frozen if heat was held onto by albedo alone. not to mention that if you were to reject the simplest of radiative transfer you would also have to discard all of stellar physics. we would have no theory to explain why the photosphere of stars would be as far out as it is, we would have no way to explain why stars emit close to a black body distribution of wavelengths. heck we wouldn't even be able to explain why our atmosphere is opaque to certain wavelengths of light, something that is verifiably true. it takes just a little bit of astrophysics to see how climate denial just doesn't stand up to any scrutiny. i wish i could just walk up to these people with the full weight of physics because i actually studied this shit and they don't understand the most simple of scientific concepts.

i keep seeing all these arguments, looking just at graphs and "oh look there's a correlation" then the other person says "no no look at THIS graph". but like there's tons of things that if you just assume no correlation between these variables then you would have to throw out TONS of basic physical concepts, but i never see anyone catching them on that basis. like forget the graphs explain how your theory works with literally anything else in the universe. explain why the earth isn't frozen, explain why stars have the apparent size that they do, explain the spectrum of stars, explain literally any of it, because we have a theory that works and works astonishingly well on basically every large body in space with anything resembling an atmosphere yet for CO2 on earth you make a special exception. its so infuriating

text: I was really angry about the claim around 28:00 because this Oliver idiot's argument was that temperature causes CO2 to rise. At the bottom of the huge troughs, at the end of an ice age, the orbital tilt of the earth changes in such a way as to increase the earth's temperature. Sea water, which when cooler retains more CO2, heats up. This means it releases more CO2, so CO2 levels begin to increase. This CO2 increase then causes the temperature to increase rapidly, due to the greenhouse effect, bringing the earth out of an ice age very quickly. That's why that graph proves this dumbass wrong

text:
A few more things. First, the forests in California, as I remember, are mostly owned by the federal government, followed closely by private individuals, think it's like low 50% and mid 40% respectively, with something like 3% owned by California. So this dude wants the government out of the way so individuals can take care of all of it, but a lot of the fires happened on private land. They aren't good, either.

Second, he said you can't fire up a solar plant with solar, which is technically true but also idiotic. Yes, the first solar plant can't be fired up with solar. After that, yes, you can fire up other solar plants with solar.

Lastly, I wish Vaush had stuck with the question of why the governments of the world created this conspiracy in order to control people. Typically, when governments do shit like that, it's for a purpose. Control for the sake of control might make sense in some countries in certain situations, but the majority of major countries? Why would they do that? They would do it for either power or money, and this conspiracy doesn't really work for either. It might help some people get elected, but only because they differ from their opponent on the issue, which is easily rectified if they wanted to. I don't get it.

Regardless, if anyone has questions after this debate, check out potholer's channel. He is awesome when it comes to covering climate change.

text:
That one graph over 100s of millions of years is misleading, because over that long time scales, the sun's energy output is very relevant. Over its life time, the sun actually became hotter, until it goes into its red giant phase. So when you go further back, the sun was very faint, at least relative to today. The earth was still warm back then since the CO2 concentration was very high, so the two canceled each other out. That's why if you were to correlate CO2 and temperature, you wouldn't get any correlation, just like you wouldn't get any correlation with ONLY the sun and temperature. But if you were to factor in both the sun and CO2, then you do get a fairly good correlation. Potholer54 did a good video on this, but I don't remember which video. I think it was one on christopher monckton.

He was right about the "gap". There is a small delay between temperature rise and CO2 rise, which isn't surprising since the driving force of these cycles is the malinkovitch cycles. When that drives a small increase in temperature, it will lead to a rise in CO2 level from melting permafrost and degassing from the ocean. But that will also generate a feedback loop.

Increased temperature can result in increased CO2 levels. This has happened in the past with the milankovich cycle. Since the earth was hotter CO2 in the oceans became less soluble causing it to diffuse out of soln into the atmosphere. This caused the atmosphere to become even hotter which causes even more CO2 to diffuse into the atm resulting in a positive feedback loop. 

This doesn't explain today's temperature however due to the fact that the temperature is simply rising too fast.

text:
Dear Vaush, Regarding your insistence that your opponent provide English articles only, as you are unable to read German, There exists a Firefox extension available at addons.mozilla.com that translates PDF documents into your language!
Also, you have a real gift for exposing the bad faith with which others argue!
Unfortunately, at 29:18 (either in bad faith or mistakenly) your rhetorical question expressing incredulity is moot (irrelevant to arguing against) the point he was making.  He asserted that the empirical data showed temperature lead CO2 levels by 800 years, to which you asked "Why would rising temperature increase CO2 levels?".  The mere statement that a given relationship exists among the values reported in the dataset can only be disproven by demonstrating that the claim is incorrect.  The only other possible refutation is that the recorded data is not a faithful representation of the empirical observations claimed.  He had no obligation to respond to this question, yet he refuted it with vagaries.  In truth, there is at least 1 well known mechanism by which a rise in temperature releases CO2, the sublimation of the clathrate form of Methane Hydrate formerly sequestered in the depths of the ocean, or beneath permafrost!
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clathrate

text:
The CO2 lags temperature for a very good and very well known reason. The solubility of CO2 in water is temperature dependant:

https://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/gases-solubility-water-d_1148.html

i.e. temperature goes up, CO2 solubility goes down, CO2 released, temperature goes up again. This is a basic feedback loop.

If he is a scientist, why doesn't he know this? Everyone knows this in climate science. It's pathetic to wheel out these old talking points, all they do is demonstrate a spectacular lack of awareness of the field. Or dishonesty.

text:
28:51 Science teacher here!  Rising temperatures do result in rising CO2 levels.  Cold water is able to trap CO2 better than warm water.  One of the reasons the earth's temperature fluctuates is because the earth "wobbles".  The angle of the tilt of the earth's axis fluctuates over time, resulting in warmer and cooler periods.  When this causes a warmer period, it causes the oceans to release CO2, which act as a greenhouse gas and further warm the earth.  This is why we actually see rises in temperatures leading rises in CO2 levels.  

CO2 is both a cause and effect of rising temperatures.  This is one reason there is a temperature threshold we need to keep global average temperatures under.  If the earth gets just a little too warm, it will both cause the oceans to release CO2 and melt the ice caps which reflect some sunlight back into space and release CO2 and other more potent greenhouse gases, further warming the earth.  So if we let the earth get a little too warm, it will result in the earth getting much warmer than the amount predicted by human CO2 emission models alone.

text:
To answer that one question about CO2 being good for plants, anyone who has done research into this will know that that is some dumb shit. Increasing CO2 does increase photosynthesis, but it also increases the temperature which affects plants in other ways. Transpiration is what happens when plants absorb CO2 and expel water. Increasing temperature increases transpiration rate, which is good up until a certain point but when the temperature and transpiration rate gets too high, it actually decreases photosynthesis which means less oxygen.
So no. More CO2 in the atmosphere doesn't benefit plants.

text: The reason why more carbon dioxide is actually bad for plants is because, well yes, it might seem like extra CO2, which plants rely on for food (conversion to sugars via photosynthesis), would be a good thing, the way that plants obtain CO2 is by opening their stomata, small openings on their leaves. The thing is, while stomata are open, the plant is allowing a two way flow of gasses, both in and out, so while the plant is gaining CO2, it is also losing water, in the form of vapor. When it becomes warmer, the plant loses more water when it opens its stomata. Plants have evolved in very interesting and different ways to combat this problem depending on their climate, so as Vaush said, flora and fauna are optimized for their climates. The thing is that CO2 makes up so little of our atmosphere in terms of volume that the extra CO2 is of little benefit to the plants, whereas the detrimental effects of increased average temperatures are much worse for them.

text: Idk if you say it later but it's killing me that you haven't. Nobody's claiming a 1:1 ratio of carbon emissions and temperature. The claim is that carbon emissions are a factor in the gradual increase in global temp & contribute to climate change. Which is supported by the data collected in the time period we'd expect to be relevant if that were the case (human history, industrial revolution, what have you). So his attempts to show you a long history of temperature fluctuations juxtaposed against relatively constant emissions are meaningless. So is the other graph that shows both fluctuating but not very cohesively. That happened during a time period when the atmosphere was completely different. Which is irrelevant, not because the atmosphere would have killed humans at the time, but because it says nothing about whether the current trend we're seeing is likely to continue.

text:
So, I like science. I looked into global warming back in the late 90's and early 00's. I was like "yep, I can cook a hotdog in my microwave." So I looked into the IPCC report to see what they wanted to do. There were no suggestions on how to cook my choice of hotdogs, only an imperative to have much smaller hotdogs. The hotdogs they describe don't sound anything like the hotdogs I know.

Metaphorical hotdogs aside, I know I can cook a hotdog in my microwave with a small adaptation. 

So, I think the proper argument here should be mitigation vs adaptation.

text:
Hes spouting every old climate change denial argument that exists, and to be honest Vaush did not know some of them apparently. 
CO2 and Temperatur do not directly correlate if you ignore solar activity, if you include that they match up nearly perfectly. 
Co2 does lag a few hundred years behind Temperatur in historical ice ages which is also well understood: The Sun initiates climate change by increasing or decreasing its energy output which leads to co2 beeing released or captured (mainly by the oceans) which then becomes the driving force of the climate change. So CO2 lags temperature in the beginning but then leads it later on.  
Next he said that the sun is responsible for climate Change: Solar activity is currently going down while temperatures are going up so its fairly easy to disprove that Solar activity is responsible for our current climate development.

text: Just a small point: I'm pretty sure that the NOAA data does show a small temperature increase (due to cycles around the sun) followed by a larger CO2 increase (from dissolved CO2 in glaciers and oceans) that creates a positive feedback loop with the temperature until the earth's cycle resets. So the graph shows that while in the past temperature increase slightly preceded CO2 increase, that CO2 increase led to a much larger temperature increase. So while it still proves that CO2 and temperature are related, it also shows that they influence each other to form a positive feedback loop which is even more dangerous.

text:
Fun fact: he's actually right about temperature rising BEFORE CO2. He's just wrong about why.

CO2 dissolves in water. The colder the water, the more CO2 can saturate it.

So temperature rises a bit, the oceans release some CO2, and that causes a feedback loop that dumps LOADS of CO2 into the atmosphere while pushing temperatures up higher as a result.

text: I definitely don't agree with the German guy here, but this comment seems to be ignorant of what he is arguing. Look up what the definition of "greenhouse effect" and you will find that phrase refers to the effect on planets, not any instance of heat from radiation being trapped including actual greenhouses. He is arguing that gases in our atmosphere do not trap heat in that way.
author: Brandon W

text: ¬†@Chore Boy¬† Thats actually not true at all. An empty glass house is far cooler than one with plants.
author: Gage Acosta

text: ¬†@Gage Acosta¬† not if the sun is shining mate. But any enclosed space with living or decomposing biomass will be warmer than the exact same space but sterile, as life is exothermic. Add a radiative heat source and a medium with any heat capacity and a radiative index lower than the rate at which you add energy and you have a greenhouse effect. The glass greenhouse works because, among other things, the barrier literally prevents the warmed air from leaving. At full scale earth is essentially a closed system.

First, the cover of low clouds is expected to decrease in the tropics as global temperatures rise, reducing their parasol effect. Second, it is well understood that high clouds will move into higher regions of the atmosphere as it warms, making them more effective blankets. These warming effects may be mitigated slightly by an increase in the thickness of clouds at high latitudes only, particularly over the Southern Ocean around Antarctica, but this will not cancel out the overall warming effect.

While we do know that clouds will likely amplify global warming, there is still a great deal of uncertainty about how strong this effect will be."

Yep clouds will amplify AGW but by how much? Not enough is known.

text:
¬†@Defixiones 1¬† Hmmm, there are some interesting things to be viewed as a super-organism, but I don't think a planet would be one of them.

Planets do not propagate and they do not need to maintain homeostasis to exist.

A living organism will cease operation and decompose once they are no longer able to maintain homeostasis. A planet continues to exist unless it is broken up by meteors or black holes, regardless of its internal state.
author: jajjfajsidjoigfe

text: ¬†@jajjfajsidjoigfe¬† You need a healthy dose of animism my guy. The world is much better when you try to respect it rather than view it as things to turn into profit.
author: Haruhiro Grimgar

text:
¬†@Haruhiro Grimgar¬† I do think animism is an interesting concept, but you don't need to say that things that obviously aren't alive are alive.

Basically, you can say that inanimate things have souls and should be respected without saying that they are living things and thus conflating them with us.

Using language like "mother earth" and taking it literally kind of misses the point that most people view it as metaphorical.

You don't have to personify to animate. Let the rock be a rock, but reference its intrinsic properties rather than bestowing personhood on it.
author: jajjfajsidjoigfe

text:
¬†@jajjfajsidjoigfe¬† The thing is when you attach the idea that all things have a soul it adds some level of sanctity to them. You should show respect or acknowledge your actions in some way. If you view a forest and trees as nothing but clumps of wood, leaves, and animals to be slaughtered then why would you care if it gets destroyed for profit? Why would you care if a river gets so poluted to the point it can be set on fire if it is coincidentally there and you can profit from it. If we were given dominion over other animals and their fate how are they any different than some allowance our parent gives us?

Animism adds value to things in a way that demands more caution and respect. A forest isn't just an opportunity for profit or a way to limit climate change if you view it as something full of life. Earth as a collection of atoms doesn't inspire the same feeling of "we should take care of this" as Mother Gaia.

When I think of the optimal fusion of human society/technology and nature it ends up looking a bit like Hoenn from Pokemon Sapphire. They build tree houses as to limit the damage they do to a forest because the forest is just an important part of nature. They stop construction when it will be actively harmful to the planet and creatures within it.

I meant it jokingly originally but I do think a lot of the issues humanity faces is because Christians generally making the world seem lifeless and for humans to shape at will. Of course animistic societies still cut down trees but they made sure to not ruin the entire forest out of principle (and a bit of fear.)
author: Haruhiro Grimgar

text: ¬†@LoveitorleaveitUSA#1 USA¬† imagine not realizing the difference between sex and gender
author: Ghostbite

text: Today we learned that thermodynamics don't exist
author: Perkele Vilunv√§ristykset

text:
¬†@Defixiones 1¬† But the point I'm making is that regardless of the state of flora/fauna, the planet will still be there, because in the end the planet is not the flora/fauna living on its surface. The planet will still be here even if all the flora/fauna on it dies.

Human society is like a super-organism for example. The roads stretch out like veins transporting resources and the communication infrastructure acts like the nervous system. If humans died out, society dies with it. There is a homeostasis that must be maintained otherwise it collapses and ceases to be. Societies can branch off into other distinct societies, thus propagating.

Meanwhile, you look at the planet with its fauna, and the planet exists regardless of the fauna. The fauna does not serve to preserve the ground or the water. That exists regardless and it is not propagated with the fauna.

When we talk about mother earth, we're really not talking about the planet itself, we're really just thinking about the fauna on it, as the planet itself is mostly inert rock that doesn't need us.
author: jajjfajsidjoigfe

text:
¬†@Haruhiro Grimgar¬† Like I said, you can attach the idea of soul to things without proclaiming them to be alive. That and if you don't care of the suffering of animals if they don't "have a soul" then that's pretty soulless in and of itself. I don't think you can replace compassion with metaphysical abstractions. In the end the fight for animal welfare is the fight for compassion.

Animals already have value even if they don't have whatever a soul would be. Or rather, they should be respected as sentient creatures regardless of whether we can find value in them.

I agree we should take care of nature and respect animals, but we should respect them as fellow sentient beings deserving of compassion and respect, not out of a brotherhood of special endowed existences that all other non-imbued things exist to serve. Even if animism has merit I would not want to play into the Christian worldview of spiritual exceptionalism.

I also agree that Christianity has a terrible outlook on non-human life. Keep looking into animism, but I would advise you to divorce yourself of Christian ideas while doing so.
author: jajjfajsidjoigfe

text: ¬†@LoveitorleaveitUSA#1 USA¬† r/onejoke
author: D. Nikolicic

text:
¬†@jajjfajsidjoigfe¬† Animism is pretty far away from Christianity. It has pagan origins, not Christian. I specifically said that Christianity doesn't utilize the concept (except for that not even 1% of Celtic Christians which is Paganism-lite.)

And honestly, our definitions are probably not the same here. I use animism as an extra reason to show compassion to nature. Part of animism is that everything has a soul and in part, everything is alive and deserves respect and at least some level of reverence. I think that any given crystal, tree, frog, bird, or person are all alive and have souls and deserve respect and dignity (except ted cruz.)

You phrased it as something living I phrased it initially as having a soul but I believe it is almost the same. They have some kind of life-force or should be seen as having one. We shouldn't kill an animal or cut down a tree or even dam a river without some type of acknowledgement that it is a living being similar to ourselves and however we treat it will have consequences for the world and ecosystem.

Christians view the earth as something humans basically own. The only thing with souls are humans and Yhwh + crew. The forest nearby is only there to serve humans. These cows are meant to supply food for us. These rivers are there to make sure we can get water. And Christianity has dominated Western culture and thought. I would argue this even affects atheists or has similarities to atheism. You have to add compassion into these ideologies to preserve nature rather than it being inherent to animism.

Animism inherently limits how much you should be able to do to the environment for personal gain. A forest isn't there solely as a pool of resources humans get to decide how to use. But a forest is a living breathing creature that should we abuse will have negative consequences we probably don't know about (I doubt they knew cutting down whole forests in the 1800s would contribute to climate change.) We should respect it because it is alive and has potential. We need resources like food, wood, land, etc but we shouldn't take it without consideration. Though for a slight joke I do think it would be fine to force all disease-carrying mosquitoes to go extinct, they can f*ck right off.
author: Haruhiro Grimgar

text: ¬†@jajjfajsidjoigfe¬†¬† And I consider things alive if they have a soul and all alive things have a soul. The terms are very similar to me. But my list of what does and doesn't have a soul is as arbitrary and changes as much as what other people consider alive. Earth as a planet has a soul, the crystals at the gem&mineral show have a soul, you and I have souls, all of the things I listed are alive in some way. But I have trouble saying that any given grain of sand has a soul and I say confidently that stillborns have no soul. But, the universe is so complex I think it is insane to believe humanity could even come close to fully understanding it. I have my interpretation as everyone else has theirs. I just think animism is more beneficial.
author: Haruhiro Grimgar
